Name: Herba Artemisiae Yinchenhao
yin chen hao
Biological: Artemisia scoparia Waldst. et Kit. (濱蒿)

Geography: Artemisia capillaris Thunb.: Shaanxi, Shanxi, Anhui
Artemisia scoparia Waldst. et Kit.: northeastern China, Hebei, Shandong
Maladies Treated: 風癢瘡疥 (wind-itch sores and scabies)
Medical Function: Clears infection of the Liver and Gallbladder
Leaves can be used for mosquito repellent
Samples of Formulae: yin chen hao tang (茵陳蒿湯)
Contraindications: Not to use in qixu (qi deficiency) type of jaundice. 黃疸而有氣虛症狀者忌用。
Research: On Viral Hepatitis: yin chen hao decoction and volatile oil have no effect on rabbit serum transaminases (ALT, AST) that was poisoned by carbon tetrachloride toxin that caused hepatitis, but the latter can make hepatitis rabbits increased food intake. There was no improvement of mortality and liver disease of mice with viral hepatitis. Yin chen hao tang decoction can promote regeneration effect on liver cells of rabbits.[1]
Chemical Ingredients: Flavonoids: areapillin[1]; isoareapillin[8]; cirsimauitin; cirsilineol; genkwanin[6]; isorhamnetin; quercetin[9]; rhamnocitrin[6]; eupatolitin; hyperin; cacticin; isorhamnetin-e-glucoside[9]; eupalitin[3]; 7-methyl-aromadendrin[4]; rutin; quercetin-3-glucogalactoside; quercetin-3, 7-rutinosodigalactoside; kaempferol-e-glucogalactoside[16].
Cinnamic and other organic acids: capillartemisin A, B; deoxycapillartemisin[8,11]; chlorogenic acid[12]; salicylic acid; azelaic acid; pyrogallol tannins[13]; oxalic acid[14].
Volatile oil (1): capillen; O-methoxycapillen; capillin[15]; capillianol; norcapillene[16]; capillon[17]; neocapillene[18]; dehydrofalcarinone; dehydrofalcarinol; 1-phenyl-2, 4-hexa-dyne-1-ol[19].
Volatile oil (2): alpha-pinene; beta-pinene; p-cymene; carene; alpha-terpineol; acetylborneol[19]; geraniol acetate; 1, 8-eucalyptol; 1-thujone; carvone; thujylalcohol[19].
Volatile oil (3): beta-elemene; beta-caryophyllene; alpha-humulene[21]; ar-curcumene[15]; cadinene; caryophyllene epoxide[22].
Aldehydes and ketones: p-hydroxy-acetophenone[13]; methylhepthylketone[24]; vanillin[20]; butylaldehyde; furaldehyde[24].
References: [1] Helongjiang Medical Science, 2004, 27th vol, 01 issue, 11-12 pages
Further Reading: Ref: 中藥現代研究與臨床應用。學苑出版社。

Name: luo shi teng
Other name: wan zi jin yin 萬字金銀

Maladies Treated: Waist and knee pain (腰膝痠痛)
Postpartum body pain with joints red, hot and swelling (產後身疼，關節紅腫灼痛) — as the indication for Qing Re Chu Bi Tang
Medical Function: Antibiotic effect: inhibits Staphylococcus aureus and Shigella.
Dosage: In decoction: 5 to 15 g. 煎劑：5～15 克。
Samples of Formulae:
For postpartum arthritis [3]
Name of Formula: Qing Re Chu Bi Tang
Application: Pain in the body, red, hot and swelling in joints
Effect: Clears heat and disperses dampness, dispels wind and invigorates blood (清熱散濕，疏風活血)
Composition: ren dong teng (Honeysuckle vine) 30 g, wei ling xian (Clematis root) 9 g, qing feng teng (Sinomenium vine) 15 g, hai feng teng (Kadsura pepper vine) 15 g, luo shi teng (Star jasmine vine) 15 g, fang ji (Stephania tetrandra root) 9 g, sang zhi (Mulberry twig) 30 g, zhui di feng (Zhui Di Feng) 9 g.
Directions: Boil with water and use as tea.

For arthritis:
Composition: luo shi teng (Star jasmine vine) 30 g, wu jia pi (Acanthopanax root bark) 30 g, niu xi (Achyranthes root) 15 g.
Directions: Simmer with water. Add some rice wine and use as tea. [5]

Chinese dosage version for the above postpartum formula (劉奉伍婦科經驗): 忍冬藤1兩，威靈仙3錢，青風藤5錢，海風藤5錢，絡石藤5錢，防己3錢，桑枝1兩，追地風3錢。
Contraindications: Not to use in cases of yang deficient with spleen deficient and with diarrhea. 陽虛兼脾虛易瀉泄者忌服。
Research:
Anti-inflammatory effect reported. [4]

The decoction of the herb relieved histamine-induced contraction of tracheal muscles in guinea pig. [2]

Maladies Treated: cough with difficulty in expelling phlegm
emotional and disorientation with abundance of phlegm
breast abscess (乳癰) swollen and painful
early stage of sores (瘡癰初起)
Medical Function: Expectorant effect: In studies with mice, a water decoction of 15 g/kilo of body weight, taken internally, had an expectorant effect. This could be because the ingredient saponin stimulates the mucus lining of the stomach, which in turn triggers the bronchii to secrete more mucus. According to the traditional Materia Medica, the part of yuan zhi used is the skin of the root; now the whole root is used, including the middle part, but chemically the skin and the middle part are different. With mice, using the skin alone, the smallest effective amount is 1.25 g/kilo. Using the middle wooden part of the root alone, 50 g/kilo had no effect at all. The wooden part of the root contains very little saponin — only 4% of the amount contained in the skin. There is also a report that 1 g/kilo of yuan zhi decoction infused into the stomachs of anesthetized dogs had no expectorant effect. (animal experiments where specified)
Anti mutation, anti cancer effect (抗突變﹐抗癌作用)
Dosage: 5 to 10 g in decoction. 5 ~ 10 克。入煎劑。
Samples of Formulae:
Kong sheng zheng zhong dan 孔聖枕中丹
tian wang bu xin dan 天王補心丹
Contraindications: Not to use in cases of heat is abundance, and where heat toxin and the body functions are over active. Use caution in cases of pixu (spleen deficient). 實熱熾盛﹐熱毒陽盛者忌服，脾虛者慎服。

Medical function:
(1). Expectorant 
            effect
 In studies 
            with mice, a water decoction of 15g/kilo of body weight, taken internally, 
            had an expectorant effect. This could be because the ingredient saponin 
            stimulates the mucus lining of the stomach. This in turn triggers the 
            bronchii to secrete more mucus. According to the traditional Materia 
            Medica, the part of yuan zhi that has been used is the skin of the root. 
            But now the whole root is used, including the middle part. But according 
            to chemical ingredients, the skin of the root and the middle part are 
            different. With mice, using the skin alone, the smallest effective amount 
            is 1.25 grams/kilo. Using the middle wooden part of the root alone, 
            the amount of 50 grams/kilo has no effect at all. The wooden part of 
            the root contains very little saponin -- only 4 per cent of the amount 
            contained in the skin. There is also a report that 1 gram /kilo of yuan 
            zhi decoction infused into the stomachs of anesthetized dogs had no 
            expectorant effect.
